title: Morrison urged to push banks into funding financial counsellors
text:
"It is appropriate for industry to participate and contribute to the increase in the availability of and access to financial counsellors and for additional funds, bolstering current state, territory and Commonwealth governments’ contributions, to be provided by industry sources."

She said the bank funding would enable an increase in financial counselling services.

About 500 financial counsellors already provide face-to-face help for 125,000 people every year.

The government will release its response to the review’s recommendations later this year but the initial signs show there is support for such a measure.

Minister for Families and Social Services Anne Ruston said the government "accepted the aims of the recommendations" and would work with the sector and broader industry to consider and develop the government response".

Sharing the costs

"The Morrison government understands how important it is for the financial counselling sector to be well positioned to support Australians in need of financial advice and advocacy.

“The review confirms that Australia has high-quality financial counselling services and provides a basis for future growth of the sector based on real experiences and expert advice,” Senator Ruston said.

Advertisement

However, the government has hinted that, over time, the costs should be borne by a broader section of the public rather than just the banks.

"[The review] also identifies opportunities for the broader business community including the banks, utility providers and telcos to identify Australians who are struggling with their finances earlier and to contribute to funding the sector which helps stop people falling further into debt," Ms Ruston said.

Labor is likely to put pressure on the government to accept the recommendations, given it announced this year a $640 million "fairness fund", including $160 million a year raised from the banks, to pay for financial counsellors.

In February, Commissioner Kenneth Hayne recommended that financial counsellors be given “predictable and stable funding”.

The review also recommends that the federal government "immediately take steps" to establish an independent body to be responsible for the coordination of financial counselling services.

The release of the review comes a day after the government released consultation draft regulations and legislation to remove the Corporations Act exemption for funeral expenses policies so they can be treated the same as other financial products.

The move is in response to the royal commission's views that many Indigenous people in regional and remote communities were being misled into buying funeral insurance.
description: The Morrison government is being urged to force the big banks to help fund a doubling of financial counselling services across the country over the next four years.
